data.meta_description: Cinema in the Arab world has been the subject of varied and rigorous studies, but most have focused on films as text, pr...

Introduction: New histories and approaches to cinema in the Arab world

Part I: Arab cinema histories: Distribution, exhibition and audiences

Chapter 1: Misr abroad: Trading Egyptian films in colonial Maghreb

Chapter 2: ‘Le Roi du Cinéma’: Joseph Seibarras and North African film exhibition, 1925–45

Chapter 3: Access for the Axis: The battle for ideological supremacy on Middle Eastern, North African and Turkish cinema screens between 1933 and 1945

Chapter 4: Egyptian women’s empowerment and early cinema-going

Chapter 5: Anti-colonial masculinity, the Catholic Film Center and the screening of religious difference in 1950s Egypt: The multiple lives of Husayn Sidqi’s Night of Power

Chapter 6: Bollywood film traffic: Shaping routes for Hindi films in the Arab world, 1954–2014

Chapter 7: The business of cinemas in Ismailia with a case study of Ghweba Cinema: An interview with Abbas Ghweba and Tareq Ghweba

Chapter 8: Cinema-going in Egypt in the long 1960s: Oral histories of pleasure and leisure

Part II: Contemporary issues of circulation, experience and memory

Chapter 9: Film distribution and exhibition in Tunisia since 2011: Is cinema-going back in style?

Chapter 10: Gatekeepers or facilitators?: MAD Solutions and other film distribution networks for Arab cinema

Chapter 11: A new online cinema audience?: An interview on Aflamuna with Jad Abi Khalil

Chapter 12: A taste for cinema: Saudi Arabia’s mediated transitional public film culture

Chapter 13: The multifunctional cinema exhibition space at the turn of the century: A dialogue

Chapter 14: The visual nation: Film, soft power and Egypt as a community of spectators
